metadata.description: Multi-hop reasoning test data for Ucotron knowledge graph evaluation

facts.subject: Ada Lovelace
facts.context: Ada Lovelace worked closely with Charles Babbage on the Analytical Engine, writing the first algorithm intended for machine processing.

facts.subject: Charles Babbage
facts.context: Charles Babbage designed and invented the Analytical Engine, a general-purpose mechanical computer concept from the 1830s.

facts.subject: Analytical Engine
facts.context: The design principles of Babbage's Analytical Engine directly inspired the architecture of ENIAC, one of the first electronic computers.

facts.subject: ENIAC
facts.context: ENIAC was built at the University of Pennsylvania's Moore School of Electrical Engineering, completed in 1945.

facts.subject: Alan Turing
facts.context: Alan Turing worked at Bletchley Park during World War II, where he led the effort to break the Enigma cipher.

facts.subject: Bletchley Park
facts.context: Bletchley Park is located in Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire, England.

facts.subject: Alan Turing
facts.context: Alan Turing invented the concept of the Turing Machine in 1936, a mathematical model of computation.

facts.subject: Turing Machine
facts.context: The Turing Machine became the theoretical foundation of modern computer science, defining what is computable.

facts.subject: Linus Torvalds
facts.context: Linus Torvalds created the Linux kernel in 1991 while a student at the University of Helsinki.

facts.subject: Linus Torvalds
facts.context: Linus Torvalds studied computer science at the University of Helsinki in Finland.

facts.subject: University of Helsinki
facts.context: The University of Helsinki is the oldest and largest university in Finland, located in Helsinki.

facts.subject: Linux
facts.context: The Linux kernel powers the Android operating system, used by billions of mobile devices worldwide.

facts.subject: Android
facts.context: Android is developed by Google, which acquired Android Inc. in 2005.

facts.subject: Google
facts.context: Google is headquartered at the Googleplex in Mountain View, California.

facts.subject: Google
facts.context: Google was co-founded by Larry Page and Sergey Brin in 1998 while they were PhD students at Stanford.

facts.subject: Larry Page
facts.context: Larry Page studied computer science at Stanford University, where he began the research that led to Google.

facts.subject: Stanford University
facts.context: Stanford University is located in Palo Alto, in the heart of Silicon Valley, California.

facts.subject: Tim Berners-Lee
facts.context: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989 while working at CERN.

facts.subject: Tim Berners-Lee
facts.context: Tim Berners-Lee worked at CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, in Geneva.

facts.subject: CERN
facts.context: CERN is located near Geneva, on the Franco-Swiss border.

facts.subject: World Wide Web
facts.context: The World Wide Web is built on top of TCP/IP, the fundamental communication protocol of the Internet.

facts.subject: TCP/IP
facts.context: TCP/IP was co-designed by Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn, often called the fathers of the Internet.

facts.subject: Vint Cerf
facts.context: Vint Cerf works at Google as Chief Internet Evangelist, advocating for open Internet standards.

facts.subject: Ada Lovelace
facts.context: Ada Lovelace was born in London, England in 1815, the daughter of Lord Byron.

facts.subject: Linus Torvalds
facts.context: Linus Torvalds also created Git in 2005, the distributed version control system used by most software projects.

facts.subject: Git
facts.context: Git is the core technology used by GitHub, the world's largest code hosting platform.

facts.subject: GitHub
facts.context: GitHub was acquired by Microsoft in 2018 for $7.5 billion.

facts.subject: Microsoft
facts.context: Microsoft is headquartered in Redmond, Washington.

facts.subject: Helsinki
facts.context: Helsinki is the capital and largest city of Finland.

facts.subject: Mountain View
facts.context: Mountain View is a city in Silicon Valley, the global center of high technology and innovation.

queries.question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
In what city did the creator of Linux study?
queries.path_description: Linus Torvalds --created--> Linux; Linus Torvalds --studied_at--> University of Helsinki --located_in--> Helsinki

queries.question: Where was the World Wide Web invented (city)?
queries.path_description: Tim Berners-Lee --invented--> WWW; Tim Berners-Lee --worked_at--> CERN --located_in--> Geneva

queries.question: What company develops the OS powered by Linux?
Where is the company that acquired GitHub headquartered?
What did the person who worked at Bletchley Park invent?
queries.path_description: Alan Turing --worked_at--> Bletchley Park; Alan Turing --invented--> Turing Machine

queries.question: What is the theoretical foundation established by the invention of the person who worked at Bletchley Park?
queries.path_description: Alan Turing --worked_at--> Bletchley Park; Alan Turing --invented--> Turing Machine --foundation_of--> Computer Science

queries.question: Where is the headquarters of the company that develops the OS powered by Linux?
Who designed the protocol that the World Wide Web is built on?
queries.path_description: Tim Berners-Lee --invented--> WWW --built_on--> TCP/IP --designed_by--> Vint Cerf

queries.question: In what city is the university where the founder of Google studied?
queries.path_description: Google --founded_by--> Larry Page --studied_at--> Stanford University --located_in--> Palo Alto

queries.question: Where is the company that acquired the platform built on the version control system created by Linus Torvalds?
queries.path_description: Linus Torvalds --created--> Git --used_by--> GitHub --acquired_by--> Microsoft --headquartered_in--> Redmond
